title: AI Due Diligence: Avoiding Costly Mistakes in Tech Investments | Melania Calinescu Explains

rawLines.text: Today on Just Curious, I'm joined by
Melania Konescu, a PhD mathematician,
strategic AI adviser, and the founder of
AI for All Solutions. Melania helps
executives and investors evaluate where
AI belongs in their businesses, how it
creates real value, and how to spot the
difference between marketing and actual
innovation. Today we'll talk about the
biggest misconceptions around AI, what
real due diligence looks like, and how
she helped a private equity firm avoid
overpaying for a healthcare technology
company by uncovering hidden risks
behind their flashy demo. Melania,
welcome to Just Curious. Happy to be
here, Ste. You've worked across Europe
and Silicon Valley as both a builder and
a strategist. What first pulled you into
the world of AI? first and foremost was
my passion for mathematics which is why
I ended up having a PhD in applied
mathematics. I do love solving complex
problems that create practical impact
and yeah that took me to being a data
scientist, building models that solve
actual business problems and then that
span the full length of driving strategy
as SVP AI because as technology evolves
we do want to use that technology for
creating real value in society. And
throughout my entire career building AI
ML systems, I was always puzzled not
just by the mathematical problem that I
was solving, but also how that plays out
in the full organization and how we
align technical possibilities with
business strategy. How do we make sure
that technology is what drives growing
the business altogether? And I often
very often believe that that gap because
it always exists. I'm pretty sure
everybody that is listening has
experienced this at least once. The gap
between technical side and business side
because they speak different languages.
Yeah. What AI has done now with the
ubiquitous use of tools such as Chad DPT
is basically kind of bridging that gap a
little bit because we do use it and we
feel like we understand it a little bit
more. But then it created a different
type of gap that of the full confusion
that is around this massive technology
that I know people fear that one day it
will just come and take over everything
and also the the hype that is driving
now executives and investors in
implementing AI tools right now or
throwing money at everything that is AI
first and just looking at flashy demos
left and right and not really really
understanding what the technology is. So
that's what brought me to where I am
today. I do want to help people really
peel the onion layers on what AI is and
fundamentally is just a collection of
very sophisticated mathematical models.
And since I do love math and solving
problems, I want to transfer that over
to uh people that have to now bring AI
into their businesses as they need to
evolve as we are all as a society uh
kind of demanding for that evolution of
the technology as well and organizations
with it. Many companies want to do
something with AI but they're not sure
what. How do you help them figure out
what actually matters? Yes, that is
definitely the most common question I
receive and the number one step that I I
start is what are your customer problems
because in this world of flashy demos
and let's be AI first that's the
fundamental question that we often
overlook um bu bringing AI into an
organization and building it into a
product or service that the company
sells should start from the question
what business problem are we solving
with AI not vice versa as in we got to
bring AI and then we'll figure out what
to do with it. So that's the that's the
number one step. Second, depending on
the size of the company, depending on
the industry, looking at what are the
constraints, sensitivity of the data, if
the company is big enough and has their
own AI or data science teams or
engineering teams, what are the
technical infrastructure details that we
need to take into account when we want
to bring AI into the company? So making
sure that the gap between what's
possible technically versus what we want
is not huge and can be achieved through
a reasonable length of time
implementation. Then number three is
okay as we do want we have a customer
problem that AI could solve. We have
mapped what would be the sort of
integration journey. Then three how do
we evolve? AI is the type of technology
unlike previous technologies that is
evolving incredibly fast and by the time
it it is implemented AI would have
changed evolved it will have different
tools different layers greater
understanding. So how do we also take
this type of uncertainty into account as
we make decisions today what tools to
use what products to integrate AI in. So
three first steps because addressing
these already takes quite some time and
decision- making but these are the first
three steps. We're going to walk through
an example of how you work with the
private equity case. But I'd love to dig
a little bit deeper into evolving. How
do you how do you help companies prepare
for that inevitable future change? I
would imagine that people are often
hesitant to invest in something if they
know it's going to change. That seems
logical. So knowing that AI is going to
be more powerful, the um the potential
benefits are going to look different in
the future than they do today. How do
you how do you help organizations get
comfortable with making those
investments? Now there are uh a few
ways. First of all, I I start with
having everybody really just play with
the tools. Interacting with Chad GPT or
Claude or Gemini is so easy. Just asking
questions, not really having to do
anything more technical or more
involved. Just having that interaction
and kind of having that direct
experience is a way of breaking some
some barriers. Then ideally people would
go through technical workshops
especially non-technical leaders and a
lot of executives are nontechnical
because they're they're they have a
business sense and even if they are
technical still this sophisticated
technology is not easy to grasp across
all the different angles. So going
through a technical workshop where you
can actually see a little bit deeper
what AI is and what what it does. Just
the standard sort of pattern recognition
framework. For example, when when you
classify Google photos, that was an
earlier form of what we see today being
Gen AI that just creates photos from a
text prompted. But the ancestors of that
were just being able to classify photos
given specific categories. So really
getting through that journey because AI
didn't appear overnight. So rounding the
answer basically starting with technical
workshop and being able to get a little
more tangible sense of what the
technology is and then really driving
through prototypes. The easiest way to
get over the fear and I actually I do
this a lot in my personal life. Whenever
I'm afraid of something I tend to pick
up a hobby that helps me conquer that
fear. So I bring that into my
professional life as well. Just small
prototypes. Definitely when the company
has a very tiny technical team or just
one data scientist, they will be over
the moon thrilled to build a prototype
for their business leaders to showcase
what AI could do for their products or
services. That's sort of the the key to
success. I've seen it work multiple
times and because it speaks directly to
what that organization does and how
their customers might benefit directly
from having AI implemented just then
working through such a small
experimental prototype helps you get
over that fear of not really
understanding what the technology is and
then yes being able to say we do take
the risk of whatever we implement today
might change in 6 months and kind of
starting to develop what is called And a
lot of technical leaders know this
modular implementation. So you don't
build a full system rigid as an
architecture but you build an
architecture of components. So as
technology evolves for one component.
You don't have to change the full
system. You just change that particular
component and you evolve the technology
of that component and then the system
evolves with it and that's how you build
for things that are changing and
technology is always changing. Yeah. You
mentioned step one was identifying a a
problem, a customer problem or a a
business problem. What are some signs
that a business is investing in AI
without clear like strategic alignment?
Yeah, that is unfortunately quite often
visible and very often what I see that
misalignment appearing is when the
business leaders are very strong in
wanting to have AI because they read
about it somewhere or they listen to a
podcast that talked about the coolest
latest AI tool that they uh that they
want to implement. Basically what I do
in such situations is taking that step
back of okay if if we do know what the
customer problem is if we don't it's
easy we start with defining or the top
three challenges that they would want to
solve in order for bringing further
revenue growth but if if they do have
that already mapped and then there's
still the the gap to okay what's the
technical leader saying what's the
business leader saying I just come in
and create that road map for them and I
say okay you want to solve this and this
is what your technical leader is saying
where we are today here's how we grow
together and I present myself as in this
is a road map you can all change and you
can decide what you want to do with it
and I take the role of being shot it at
in order to help mediate what the
business leader wants and what the
technical leader says is is possible you
you work with companies at different
stages of AI maturity. How do you help
leaders assess where they actually are,
not where they want to be? Yeah. Um,
actually from uh from a work I did with
um a small midsized company a few months
ago, that's where we started because
that that gap that I talked about
earlier between where their CEO thought
they were versus where their uh CTO said
they were technically, it was very big
and they just couldn't reconcile it and
they couldn't really progress in in
bringing AI into the organization. And
from that that work led to me building
this AI maturity spectrum that basically
gives a few pointers of how to identify
where your company sits and both from
like operational readiness team skills
overall industry sort of landscape and
what to do as next steps in order to ma
bring the organization to the next step.
It's it's a pretty uh simple eight uh
level spectrum and it starts with okay
in order to implement this type of tool
we need to have specific architecture or
we need to have a customer problem to to
address. Do we even understand what
machine learning is? Do we have any form
of algorithms that do anything in the
company? Do we have automated workflows?
even a small thing like sending um I
don't know a a set of expenses report to
be approved by your manager and then be
paid off by your financial department.
So even simple things like this can uh
give you the the pointers of am just AI
aware because we don't really have any
form of algorithms we don't have any
automation or yes we do have something
and now our data science team has
already built a prototype to do customer
support through assistance identifying
these elements that I I describe in in
the spectrum then helps very easily 5
minute 10-minut conversation can broad
level say okay we are at this point in
time and we can move forward by doing x
y and z. You also have a uh a framework
you call quantum humanism. Can you walk
us through the framework and how some of
the components like purpose pattern and
partnership fit together? Yes. And thank
you for bringing that up because it's
basically the underlying foundation of
everything I've I've been talking about
until now. So the quantum human humanism
framework basically comes from being
able to bridge technical sides with the
human side in in a context. I do believe
that everything has to exist but not
overlap. So clearly delineating what
humans are best at that's setting the
objectives clearly drawing the strategic
road map versus what machines excel at.
And that's the technology that's the
pattern recognition those are the
algorithms. So letting AI do what's best
at uh and humans what they're good at.
And so not expecting AI to be humanlike
intelligence but really knowing that AI
needs to follow parameters described or
set by the objectives. And then step
three is okay as AI provides an output
then that output is thrown back to
experts and leaders to evaluate given
the overall organizational context
industry context. So three pillars
purpose where humans set the objectives
of what AI should do for their business.
Second, you run uh the algorithms with
that specific set of objectives and
three you evaluate the outputs and make
decisions after that. And how does this
framework influence what kinds of
questions a CEO or an investor should
ask about AI? It kind of goes back to
what we were talking about earlier. The
the first pillar, the purpose or the
human objectives usually will take you
down the path of what kind of customer
problems we are solving. What are we
what do we want from AI? What would it
bring us if we look 2 3 years down the
line as a as a bigger organization or
expanding in different industries or
expanding the position we currently have
as a business in the industry. So those
would be the the questions definitely
executives would be able to address and
look for answers later on through
application of AI in that first pillar.
In the second pillar, you get the usual
questions of okay, where are we from a
technical perspective? Is our
architecture where is it in terms of
ability of adoption of of AI? Do we also
want to have something built in house or
do we bring in open source models that
we fine-tune and be able to specialize
them for the particular context of our
business. So these type of technical
questions will be asked and answered in
that second pillar. And then the third
pillar that being the most important is
how do we think of that collaboration
where do we plug that human in the loop
step. So we are basically able to
evaluate at all times what AI is doing
how it is answering and following the
objectives that we set what kind of
iterative decisions we might want to do
as we maybe alter objectives as we see
the output from uh from the algorithms.
I'd love to walk through an example of
how this all comes together. You shared
with me work that you've done with a
private equity firm who is focused on
making an acquisition in the healthcare
technology space. Tell us about that
engagement. Where did it start? What
what did they come to you with and then
let's walk through how you helped them
avoid making a large mistake. Yeah. uh
this uh so normally the way I work with
VCs and private equity firms is I come
in as they ask me to do a technical due
diligence on one of their portfolio
companies or they are looking to acquire
or invest into a new company and they're
not really certain that the technical
description that they received is very
solid or they feel that something might
be uh hidden or not clearly explained.
And of course, as they are going to
throw serious money at something, they
want to make sure that that they
understand all the angles. This
particular case uh is a lot more just
day-to-day life than than normal. It
started with uh one of my uh
collaborators at the private equity firm
that was completely shocked by how much
they had to uh still pay after having a
medical procedure done. And
investigating that they actually
discovered that the codes that were
written uh by the medical uh staff after
the procedure they had done were the
wrong ones and then the insurance
company just reimbured according to the
codes they received. Didn't know what
the procedure really was because
insurance companies they read the codes
and uh reimburse accordingly. So in the
full sort of healthc care sort of
financial universe um which is called
revenue cycle management um there's a
number of companies that work at
different steps in this whole workflow.
Uh that starts from patient registration
all the way to insurance verification
all the way to uh you as the patient
receiving uh money from the insurance or
having the insurance pay the claim or
you having to pay whatever it's is owed.
And uh because the length of this
workflow is so huge covers this uh very
many steps a lot of errors appear either
medical billing or in this case the the
medical codes were were wrong. and um
various startups looking to bring AI
into the health care system are
targeting this particular area of the
medical codes because this is currently
still being done almost always by humans
and it can lead to a lot of errors just
because people are overwhelmed or
systems are still legacy environments
and things are not working the way they
should. So this is an opportunity where
higher automation can actually benefit
all the players in that entire financial
workflow. And in this particular case,
the uh person of the private equity firm
because they were particularly annoyed
by the issue they were exposed to
individually looked for investing into a
company that actually helps solve this
problem.
And as they found this kind of small to
midsize healthcare technology company,
everything looked really good in their
marketing materials because they did
present something called autonomous
coding reading. So being able to really
automatically just through algorithms
interpret all these medical codes
without much human supervision. And that
seemed really too good to be true. And
that's when they brought me in to see is
this really working as automatically and
autonomously as they are saying or are
there some hidden details that we should
be aware of and that's how I started the
engagement with uh before the technical
due diligence on this particular
healthcare technology company and I did
follow my quantum humanism framework. So
I started with the purpose side. So
again what are the re the customer
problems that the company was solving.
So being able to alleviate the rather
large human effort in transferring these
codes from the medical side to the
insurance company side and um as they
have a product for doing that is their
revenue as a business fully linked to
this product. How much of this product
is truly autonomous? So truly driven by
AI or how much of it is actually still
requiring the good old traditional human
intervention. So really being able to
understand how much of the revenue that
the company was bringing in, how much of
that was created directly by by AI and
were there healthcare clients utilizing
this feature of autonomous coding or uh
not is then that means that AI was not
necessarily driving the mode of the uh
of the company just the overall uh
product. So that was the the first part.
During the engagement and during the
work that I did, I actually I did
discover that that autonomous coding was
not really as autonomous as they were
claiming in the original sort of
valuation technical uh documentation,
but it still required quite a lot of
human review. And um that how do you
sorry how do you discover that out of
curiosity? How did you find out that
what they had uh promoted was not
actually what was happening? Yeah, it
was actually quite uh quite a lot of uh
heavy conversation because they were not
very willing to share how it actually
works uh what are the sort of true
system architectures and technical
implementations because of course they
were claiming competitive sensitive and
they didn't want to share all that. But
they were also mentioning that it's it's
a feedback loop as AI interprets all
these codes automatically. There's still
a human in the loop that puts a stamp.
Initially they were saying okay this is
randomly done like a regular sort of
quality control process. But as I
actually got to speak to one of their
engineers um and this was part of the
sort of third step of the quantum uh
humanism framework. As I got to talk to
one of their engineer, one of their AI
engineers, I discovered that in fact
everything had to pass through a human
review because the more complex coding
interpretation situations those were not
in fact handled autonomously. It was
still somebody really writing down what
the uh what the code was particularly
when more complex procedures were
conducted. basically this type of
complex cases that would have benefited
a lot more from having the tool
automatically doing it. In fact, we're
still run through um humans. The
differentiation between what's a complex
case that needs to be fully done by
humans versus something that can be
partially automated was done by just
running an algorithm that this
particular engineer was in charge of.
And he was just one person. So if he
went on holiday, the system didn't
necessarily work, which was a huge huge
risk because one person dependency when
you claim full autonomous system is just
they of course are not equal. So that's
basically how
uh I uncovered what's the difference
between what they were claiming versus
how it actually worked in practice. And
what did that mean for for the
investors? Did they
ultimately pay less for this company?
Did they did they walk away from the
company? How did they use what you'd
found? So they initially they of course
wanted to walk away from it because this
this gap between the claims versus how
it actually worked in practice was was
pretty big. At the same time when we
fully assessed the technical debt, the
architecture and what their um data
science team was working towards. So
really building more complex algorithms
that can once ready do this autonomously
uh or automatically. That sort of road
map brought back the confidence that the
B firm had that the the company is
valuable. But the most the strongest
argument was the proprietary data that
they had from from their clients because
they did have a pretty steady reliable
client base that had implemented this
the system that they had. And that data
that is definitely the type of advantage
and and mode that is is hard to
replicate by somebody that just comes
into uh to the field today. even if they
do have the the tooling that uh data set
actually fine-tunes and personalizes the
model to really respond and give the the
correct output. So that was a very
strong argument plus the road map of how
they were going to improve things
brought in the end this turned into a
deal but the the value of the deal was
significantly reduced. Gotcha. Um that's
a great example of how you can use your
frameworks to undercover cover rather
but also avoid risk. I'd love to um as
we come to the end of our conversation
ask you some questions that hopefully
can inform how people pursue their own
AI uh initiatives. And I guess the first
would be what's what's one question that
every CEO should ask before approving an
AI project? should be show me the proof
because very often they get to see the
flashy demo. So something that works in
a very welldefined environment and when
you take that and you put it into real
life production ready scale very often
it it falls apart. So being able to get
to that level of let's do a trial, let's
see how this works for my particular
case because another thing that a lot of
AI tools are doing today, they try to
sell this oneizefits all type of tools
which yeah it's it's hard to really have
function easily because the data is very
different. each organization would have
a very different architecture and when
looking at the data infrastructure that
very often cancels the idea of one
sizefits-all. So number one show me the
proof of how will this work for my
particular case and um that can either
lead to a success and things can move
forward or it can be a a clear no this
is not going to happen we move on.
What's the biggest misconception you see
about AI in either pitch decks or in
boardrooms? Just one misconception. I
would say this idea of AI is humanlike
intelligence. Definitely disappears in
the boardroom. And that also creates
that gap between where business leaders
think they are versus where the
technical leaders say they are because
we interact with Chpt. We write a
question in a split second we get an
answer back. And a lot of business
leaders think that is how AI should work
in practice. You bring the tool half an
hour later it needs to be working and it
needs to do what everybody said it would
do which is it's not reality. So that
misconception of expectations versus
reality, maybe not misconception but
rather a gap. That's that's the biggest
one. And the fact that there's so much
confusion, so much hype, even I read
daily about a number of tools that will
magically solve whatever technical
problems I have. That's not possible. So
really taking that step of saying, okay,
how real is this? that will be
addressing that that m misconception
that is not human intelligence yet. You
said that the real question isn't what
if machines become more powerful but
what if humans become more powerful.
What does that mean for how leaders
should think about AI? Yes, I'm a huge
believer and again that's what I try to
promote through the quantum humanism
framework that AI is not here to replace
human judgment. It is here to enhance it
and we all become better by bringing
technology to do what technology is good
at. If you want things automated,
technology can do that. If you need to
have a collaborator that you ideate with
and you need that collaborator to really
be a clone of yours, but not really a
clone of yours to to give you different
ideas, you can use the technology for
it. If you want to quickly prototype
something just because you want to test
an idea and your team is really busy
delivering actual project and
implementations, go do that with the
technology. So I see AI as coming as a
tool very powerful tool that we should
also train ourselves in using and not
just take whatever it says as that's
that's exactly what it is and use it for
um our purposes to become better to
learn more to be more efficient.
Awesome. Melania, thank you so much for
coming by. Just curious sharing your
perspectives, examples of how you've
helped organizations not only um use AI
to create value, but also avoid making
mistakes by understanding what it's
doing and what it's not. So, yeah, thank
you for for coming by. Thank you for
having me. and uh really appreciate what
you're doing with uh just curious
bringing business leaders and AI experts

cleanText:
Today on Just Curious, I'm joined by Melania Calinescu, a PhD mathematician, strategic AI advisor, and the founder of AI4ALL Solutions. Melania helps executives and investors evaluate where AI belongs in their businesses, how it creates real value, and how to spot the difference between marketing and actual innovation. Today we'll talk about the biggest misconceptions around AI, what real AI due diligence looks like, and how she helped a private equity firm avoid overpaying for a healthcare technology company by uncovering hidden risks behind their flashy demo. Melania, welcome to Just Curious. Happy to be here, Ste. You've worked across Europe and Silicon Valley as both a builder and a strategist. What first pulled you into the world of AI? First and foremost was my passion for mathematics, which is why I ended up having a PhD in applied mathematics. I do love solving complex problems that create practical impact, and yeah, that took me to being a data scientist, building models that solve actual business problems, and then that spanned the full length of driving strategy as SVP AI because as technology evolves, we do want to use that technology for creating real value in society. Throughout my entire career building AI ML systems, I was always puzzled not just by the mathematical problem that I was solving, but also how that plays out in the full organization and how we align technical possibilities with business strategy. How do we make sure that technology is what drives growing the business altogether? I often very often believe that that gap, because it always exists. I'm pretty sure everybody that is listening has experienced this at least once, the gap between technical side and business side because they speak different languages. Yeah. What AI has done now with the ubiquitous use of tools such as Chad DPT is basically kind of bridging that gap a little bit because we do use it and we feel like we understand it a little bit more. But then it created a different type of gap, that of the full confusion that is around this massive technology that I know people fear that one day it will just come and take over everything and also the hype that is driving now executives and investors in implementing AI tools right now or throwing money at everything that is AI first and just looking at flashy demos left and right and not really really understanding what the technology is. So that's what brought me to where I am today. I do want to help people really peel the onion layers on what AI is and fundamentally is just a collection of very sophisticated mathematical models. And since I do love math and solving problems, I want to transfer that over to people that have to now bring AI into their businesses as they need to evolve as we are all as a society kind of demanding for that evolution of the technology as well and organizations with it. Many companies want to do something with AI, but they're not sure what. How do you help them figure out what actually matters? Yes, that is definitely the most common question I receive, and the number one step that I start is what are your customer problems? Because in this world of flashy demos and let's be AI first, that's the fundamental question that we often overlook, bringing AI into an organization and building it into a product or service that the company sells should start from the question, what business problem are we solving with AI, not vice versa, as in we got to bring AI and then we'll figure out what to do with it. So that's the number one step. Second, depending on the size of the company, depending on the industry, looking at what are the constraints, sensitivity of the data, if the company is big enough and has their own AI or data science teams or engineering teams, what are the technical infrastructure details that we need to take into account when we want to bring AI into the company? So making sure that the gap between what's possible technically versus what we want is not huge and can be achieved through a reasonable length of time implementation. Then number three is, okay, as we do want, we have a customer problem that AI could solve. We have mapped what would be the sort of integration journey. Then three, how do we evolve? AI is the type of technology, unlike previous technologies, that is evolving incredibly fast, and by the time it is implemented, AI would have changed, evolved, it will have different tools, different layers, greater understanding. So how do we also take this type of uncertainty into account as we make decisions today, what tools to use, what products to integrate AI in. So three first steps because addressing these already takes quite some time and decision-making, but these are the first three steps. We're going to walk through an example of how you work with the private equity case. But I'd love to dig a little bit deeper into evolving. How do you help companies prepare for that inevitable future change? I would imagine that people are often hesitant to invest in something if they know it's going to change. That seems logical. So knowing that AI is going to be more powerful, the potential benefits are going to look different in the future than they do today. How do you help organizations get comfortable with making those investments? Now there are a few ways. First of all, I start with having everybody really just play with the tools. Interacting with Chad GPT or Claude or Gemini is so easy. Just asking questions, not really having to do anything more technical or more involved. Just having that interaction and kind of having that direct experience is a way of breaking some barriers. Then ideally people would go through technical workshops, especially non-technical leaders, and a lot of executives are nontechnical because they're they're they have a business sense, and even if they are technical, still this sophisticated technology is not easy to grasp across all the different angles. So going through a technical workshop where you can actually see a little bit deeper what AI is and what what it does. Just the standard sort of pattern recognition framework. For example, when when you classify Google photos, that was an earlier form of what we see today being Gen AI that just creates photos from a text prompted. But the ancestors of that were just being able to classify photos given specific categories. So really getting through that journey because AI didn't appear overnight. So rounding the answer, basically starting with technical workshop and being able to get a little more tangible sense of what the technology is and then really driving through prototypes. The easiest way to get over the fear, and I actually I do this a lot in my personal life. Whenever I'm afraid of something, I tend to pick up a hobby that helps me conquer that fear. So I bring that into my professional life as well. Just small prototypes. Definitely when the company has a very tiny technical team or just one data scientist, they will be over the moon thrilled to build a prototype for their business leaders to showcase what AI could do for their products or services. That's sort of the the key to success. I've seen it work multiple times, and because it speaks directly to what that organization does and how their customers might benefit directly from having AI implemented, just then working through such a small experimental prototype helps you get over that fear of not really understanding what the technology is and then yes, being able to say we do take the risk of whatever we implement today might change in 6 months and kind of starting to develop what is called, and a lot of technical leaders know this, modular implementation. So you don't build a full system rigid as an architecture, but you build an architecture of components. So as technology evolves for one component, you don't have to change the full system. You just change that particular component and you evolve the technology of that component and then the system evolves with it, and that's how you build for things that are changing, and technology is always changing. Yeah. You mentioned step one was identifying a problem, a customer problem or a business problem. What are some signs that a business is investing in AI without clear like strategic alignment? Basically what I do in such situations is taking that step back of okay, if we do know what the customer problem is, if we don't, it's easy, we start with defining or the top three challenges that they would want to solve in order for bringing further revenue growth, but if if they do have that already mapped and then there's still the gap to okay, what's the technical leader saying, what's the business leader saying, I just come in and create that road map for them and I say, okay, you want to solve this and this is what your technical leader is saying, where we are today, here's how we grow together, and I present myself as in this is a road map, you can all change and you can decide what you want to do with it, and I take the role of being shot it at in order to help mediate what the business leader wants and what the technical leader says is is possible. You work with companies at different stages of AI maturity. How do you help leaders assess where they actually are, not where they want to be? Yeah. And from that that work led to me building this AI maturity spectrum that basically gives a few pointers of how to identify where your company sits and both from like operational readiness, team skills, overall industry sort of landscape and what to do as next steps in order to bring the organization to the next step. It's a pretty simple eight level spectrum and it starts with okay, in order to implement this type of tool, we need to have specific architecture or we need to have a customer problem to address. Do we even understand what machine learning is? Do we have any form of algorithms that do anything in the company? Do we have automated workflows? Even a small thing like sending I don't know, a set of expenses report to be approved by your manager and then be paid off by your financial department. You also have a framework you call quantum humanism. Can you walk us through the framework and how some of the components like purpose, pattern, and partnership fit together? Yes. And thank you for bringing that up because it's basically the underlying foundation of everything I've been talking about until now. So the quantum humanism framework basically comes from being able to bridge technical sides with the human side in in a context. I do believe that everything has to exist but not overlap. So clearly delineating what humans are best at, that's setting the objectives, clearly drawing the strategic road map versus what machines excel at. And that's the technology, that's the pattern recognition, those are the algorithms. So letting AI do what's best at and humans what they're good at. And so not expecting AI to be humanlike intelligence, but really knowing that AI needs to follow parameters described or set by the objectives. And then step three is, okay, as AI provides an output, then that output is thrown back to experts and leaders to evaluate given the overall organizational context, industry context. So three pillars: purpose, where humans set the objectives of what AI should do for their business. Second, you run the algorithms with that specific set of objectives, and three, you evaluate the outputs and make decisions after that. And how does this framework influence what kinds of questions a CEO or an investor should ask about AI? It kind of goes back to what we were talking about earlier. The first pillar, the purpose or the human objectives, usually will take you down the path of what kind of customer problems we are solving. What are we, what do we want from AI? What would it bring us if we look 2, 3 years down the line as a as a bigger organization or expanding in different industries or expanding the position we currently have as a business in the industry. So those would be the the questions definitely executives would be able to address and look for answers later on through application of AI in that first pillar. In the second pillar, you get the usual questions of okay, where are we from a technical perspective? Is our architecture, where is it in terms of ability of adoption of of AI? Do we also want to have something built in house or do we bring in open source models that we fine-tune and be able to specialize them for the particular context of our business. So these type of technical questions will be asked and answered in that second pillar. And then the third pillar, that being the most important, is how do we think of that collaboration, where do we plug that human in the loop step. So we are basically able to evaluate at all times what AI is doing, how it is answering and following the objectives that we set, what kind of iterative decisions we might want to do as we maybe alter objectives as we see the output from from the algorithms. You shared with me work that you've done with a private equity firm who is focused on making an acquisition in the healthcare technology space. Tell us about that engagement. Where did it start? This, so normally the way I work with VCs and private equity firms is I come in as they ask me to do a technical due diligence on one of their portfolio companies or they are looking to acquire or invest into a new company and they're not really certain that the technical description that they received is very solid or they feel that something might be hidden or not clearly explained. And of course, as they are going to throw serious money at something, they want to make sure that that they understand all the angles. This particular case is a lot more just day-to-day life than than normal. It started with one of my collaborators at the private equity firm that was completely shocked by how much they had to still pay after having a medical procedure done. And investigating that, they actually discovered that the codes that were written by the medical staff after the procedure they had done were the wrong ones and then the insurance company just reimbursed according to the codes they received. Didn't know what the procedure really was because insurance companies, they read the codes and reimburse accordingly. So in the full sort of healthcare sort of financial universe, which is called revenue cycle management, there's a number of companies that work at different steps in this whole workflow. That starts from patient registration all the way to insurance verification all the way to you as the patient receiving


Uh, money from the insurance or having the insurance pay the claim, or you having to pay whatever it's owed. And, uh, because the length of this workflow is so huge, it covers this, uh, very many steps. A lot of errors appear, either medical billing or, in this case, the medical codes were wrong. And, um, various startups looking to bring AI into the healthcare system are targeting this particular area of the medical codes because this is currently still being done almost always by humans, and it can lead to a lot of errors just because people are overwhelmed or systems are still legacy environments, and things are not working the way they should. So, this is an opportunity where higher automation can actually benefit all the players in that entire financial workflow. And in this particular case, the, uh, person of the private equity firm, because they were particularly annoyed by the issue they were exposed to, individually looked for investing into a company that actually helps solve this problem.

And as they found this kind of small to midsize healthcare technology company, everything looked really good in their marketing materials because they did present something called autonomous coding reading. So, being able to really automatically, just through algorithms, interpret all these medical codes without much human supervision. And that seemed really too good to be true. And that's when they brought me in to see, is this really working as automatically and autonomously as they are saying, or are there some hidden details that we should be aware of? And that's how I started the engagement with, uh, before the technical due diligence on this particular healthcare technology company, and I did follow my Quantum Humanism Framework. So, I started with the purpose side. So, again, what are the customer problems that the company was solving? So, being able to alleviate the rather large human effort in transferring these codes from the medical side to the insurance company side, and, um, as they have a product for doing that, is their revenue as a business fully linked to this product? How much of this product is truly autonomous? So, truly driven by AI, or how much of it is actually still requiring the good old traditional human intervention? So, really being able to understand how much of the revenue that the company was bringing in, how much of that was created directly by AI, and were there healthcare clients utilizing this feature of autonomous coding, or, uh, not?
